summary: This is a grand jury subpoena issued by the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York to AT&T Legal Compliance, seeking telephone records for the period 2002-2006 as part of a criminal investigation into violations of federal sex trafficking and related statutes. The document includes a request for non-disclosure to preserve the confidentiality of the investigation.

persons.name: Geoffrey S. Berman
persons.context: Issued the grand jury subpoena and signed the accompanying letter requesting non-disclosure of the subpoena to preserve investigation confidentiality.

persons.name: Geoff E. Berman
persons.role: United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York
persons.context: Signed the grand jury subpoena commanding AT&T to produce records and appear before the grand jury.

events.title: Grand Jury Appearance Date
events.description: AT&T Legal Compliance is commanded to appear before the Grand Jury for the Southern District of New York to testify and produce records.

events.title: Subpoena Issuance
events.description: The grand jury subpoena is issued to AT&T Legal Compliance for telephone records from 2002-2006.

locations: Silvio J. Mollo Building, One Saint Andrew's Plaza, New York, New York 10007
AT&T Legal Compliance, 11760 Highway 1, Suite 600, North Palm Beach, FL 33408
United States Courthouse, 40 Foley Square, Room 220, Manhattan, New York, NY
keyFacts: The subpoena seeks AT&T telephone records for the period January 1, 2002 through December 31, 2006, indicating investigators are focusing on that timeframe.

The investigation involves alleged violations of 18 U.S.C. §§ 1591 (sex trafficking), 1594(c) (attempt/conspiracy to commit sex trafficking), and 2422(b) (coercing/minoring into illegal sexual activity).
The U.S. Attorney's Office specifically requests AT&T not disclose the existence of the subpoena to any third party to preserve investigation confidentiality.
The document is part of an active federal grand jury investigation being conducted in the Southern District of New York in May 2019.
The subpoena requires production of extensive records including call details, subscriber information, text messaging records, IP history, and associated email addresses.
